sampling because as we all know there is a cost crisis in observability right now
it costs a lot of money to store all this data if we want to store the tracing
data which let's say a request goes through three different Services that's probably around six or seven different
spans that you've got for every single request that comes through your system sampling is how we keep those
costs low while providing with the ability to debug your systems at the same level as you always have
there's two different types we can do head sampling we can do tail
sampling both of them are about us retaining the full context of a whole
trace on none of the trace what it does is it reduces our storage costs our Ingress um our inest
costs egress costs all of those things because it's reducing storage it makes quering faster
it does a lot of things that are really awesome when we do head
sampling essentially we do it before the activity the user has done as created like maybe that's a HTTP
request um or a um message that's come in somebody's dropped a file on an S3
bucket or a blob storage and you've triggered something off the back of it but what that means is we've got very
little information to go on at that point you maybe know the youur well the user agent maybe the size
of the payload because you've got request
length but you don't know whether that's going to be slow you know whether that's going to be
a slow request it could be one the errors and the thing is if you knew it
was going to error at the point when the request came in maybe fix the code first
but it is the most efficient way to do sampling because it removes all of the
process overhead because if you're not going to keep the data then don't generate the data in the first place take it off the
Heap no need for it but you only have limited information
to go on now by contrast tail sampling is what everybody should be
doing at scale now tail sampling runs on a delay after you've received that first the the
root span so when the root span comes in you wait a little bit of a delay 5 seconds maybe wait for all the rest of
the spans to come in and then you can make a decision generally run as part of the collector or we have our own adaptive
tail sampler that we use that sits after the collector but it has access to all the
span data on all of the spans it can tell you whether one of
your spans errored one of your spans was a retry it can tell you whether it was
slow which means you can make a decision on whether to keep it or not it does however delay sending spans
to the back end that's a trade-off that you have to make it is memory intensive as well because it's having to store a
load of that data buffer all of that data up but it is phenomenally
useful it does however require the application to send all of the spans now
if you're running in a multi-az environment and you're sending all of your spans from your three azs to one
location that's 2third of your data that is going over cross availability zones
now if you're using a cloud platform that treats cross a traffic as a revenue
streams then that can be quite expensive these are all tradeoffs
is it cheaper for me to send it all to my vendor my back end or is it cheaper to stomach the
cross a Z cost and then send fewer items to your vendor these are all decisions
you need to make this isn't a tool that's just going to be let's just install it tomorrow and we'll be

observability it's a tool that you should be continually working with adding context
maybe removing context when it's no longer useful you should be constantly thinking
